Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: This unit investigates how people have responded to specific types of hazards and disasters. Hazards represent the potential to cause harm to people and or the environment, whereas disasters are defined as serious disruptions of the functionality of a community at any scale, involving human, material, economic or environmental losses and impacts. Hazards include a wide range of situations including those within local areas, such as fast-moving traffic or the likelihood of coastal erosion, to regional and global hazards such as drought and infectious disease.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Students undertake an overview of hazards before investigating two contrasting types of hazards and the responses to them.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Students examine the processes involved with hazards and hazard events, considering their causes and impacts, human responses to hazard events and the interconnections between human activities and natural phenomena, including the impact of climate change.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Types of hazards are commonly classified by their causes:

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Geological (or geophysical) hazards include volcanic activity, erosion, earthquakes, tsunamis, landslides and avalanches

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Hydro-meteorological (weather, climate, water) hazards include droughts, floods, storms, storm surges and bushfires

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Biological hazards include infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS and malaria, animal transmitted diseases, water borne diseases, and plant and animal invasion such as blackberries and cane toads in Australia

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Technological hazards are human induced and exacerbated hazards including oil spills, air pollution, radiation leaks, flooding primarily caused by land clearances, epidemics caused by poor living conditions and hazards caused by current climate change such as rising sea levels or increased intensification of weather events.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription:
There may be considerable interconnection between the causes and types of hazards. For example, a region may be at risk from a number of hazards: high seasonal rainfall may result
in a primary flood hazard which may in turn generate a secondary hazard of landslides.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription:
Students undertake fieldwork and produce a fieldwork report using the structure provided
(see pages 13 and 14).

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
ContentDescription: In this area of study students examine hazards and hazard events, and analyse the impacts of hazard events.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
Elaboration: They study at least two specific hazards at different scales.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
Elaboration: Students select one hazard from at least two different types of hazards listed above, for example, coastal hazards and an alien animal invasion, or floods and oil spills.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
Elaboration: The selection of hazards should allow students to use visual representations and topographical maps at various scales and to undertake fieldwork.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the nature of hazards and the impacts of hazard events at a range of scales.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of hazards
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1 and the relevant Characteristics of the study detailed on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
ContentDescription:
In this area of study students distinguish between a hazard and a hazard event, which can 
result in a disaster depending on its impact and interconnections.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
Elaboration:
They explore the nature 
and effectiveness of specific measures such as prediction and warning programs, community preparedness and land use planning, as well as actions taken after hazards become harmful 
and destructive disasters.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
Elaboration: Students consider natural and human factors influencing the nature

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
ContentDescription: of responses, considering the scale of the hazard, levels of risk due to hazards, past experiences and perceptions of similar hazards and hazard events, the capacity of government organisations and communities to act, issues and challenges that arise from responses to hazards and hazard events, available technological resources and the ability to plan and develop effective prevention and mitigation measures.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
Elaboration: Students investigate the responses to the hazards selected in Area of Study 1, with reference to a variety of locations.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse and evaluate the nature, purpose and effectiveness of a range of responses to selected hazards and disasters.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2 and the relevant Characteristics of the study detailed on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters
ContentDescription: The core assessment task for Outcome 1 is a fieldwork report of approximately 1500–2000 words (for further information see pages 13 and 14).

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Response to hazards and disasters

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: In this unit students investigate the characteristics of tourism: where it has developed, its various forms, how it has changed and continues to change and its impact on people, places and environments, issues and challenges of ethical tourism. Students select contrasting examples of tourism from within Australia and elsewhere in the world to support their investigations. Tourism involves the movement of people travelling away from and staying outside of their usual environment for more than 24 hours but not more than one consecutive year (United Nations World Tourism Organization definition). The scale of tourist movements since the 1950s and its predicted growth has had and continues to have a significant impact on local, regional and national environments, economies and cultures. The travel and tourism industry is directly responsible for a significant number of jobs globally and generates a considerable portion of global GDP.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: The study of tourism at local, regional and global scales emphasises the interconnection within and between places as well as the impacts, issues and challenges that arise from various forms of tourism. For example, the interconnections of climate, landforms, culture and climate change help determine the characteristics of a place that can prove attractive to tourists. There is an interconnection between places tourists originate from and their destinations through the development of communication and transport infrastructure, employment, and cultural preservation and acculturation. The growth of tourism at all scales requires appropriate management to ensure it is environmentally, socially, culturally and economically sustainable.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription:
Students undertake fieldwork and produce a fieldwork report using the structure provided
(see pages 13 and 14).

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
ContentDescription:
In this area of study students examine the characteristics of tourism, the location and distribution 
of different types of tourism and tourist destinations, and the factors affecting different types of tourism.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
Elaboration: Students support this investigation with contrasting examples from within Australia and elsewhere in the world.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
Elaboration: They investigate in detail at least one tourism location using appropriate fieldwork techniques, and one other location elsewhere in the world.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
Elaboration:
The selection of examples should allow students to work with a range of information sources, for example statistical data, digital images, streamed video, geospatial technologies and a variety of maps at various scales, 
as well as to undertake fieldwork.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the nature of tourism at a range 
of scales.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Characteristics of tourism
ContentDescription:
To achieve this outcome the student will draw on the key knowledge and key skills outlined in 
Area of Study 1 and the relevant Characteristics of the study detailed on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on two investigations of geographical change: change to land cover and change to land use. Land cover includes biomes such as forest, grassland, tundra, bare lands and wetlands, as well as land covered by ice and water. Land cover is the natural state of the biophysical environment developed over time as a result of the interconnection between climate, soils, landforms and flora and fauna and, increasingly, interconnections with human activity. Natural land cover is altered by many processes such as geomorphological events, plant succession and climate change.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: Students investigate two major processes that are changing land cover in many regions of the world: melting glaciers and ice sheets, and deforestation.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: They investigate the distribution and causes of the two processes. They select one location for each of the processes to develop a greater understanding of the changes to land cover produced by these processes, the impacts of these changes and responses to these changes at different scales.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: People have modified land cover to produce a range of land uses to satisfy needs such as housing, resource provision, communication and recreation. Land use change is a characteristic of both urban and rural environments and occurs at both spatial and temporal scales.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription: At a local scale students investigate land use change using appropriate fieldwork techniques and secondary sources. They investigate the processes of change, the reasons for change and the impacts of change.

Subject: Geography
ContentDescription:
Students undertake fieldwork and produce a fieldwork report using the structure provided
(see pages 13 and 14). They develop a research question and hypothesis and use both primary and secondary sources to collect data. Fieldwork techniques including geospatial technologies are employed to collect and present data.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
ContentDescription: In this area of study students undertake an overview of global land cover and changes that have occurred over time.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
Elaboration: Students investigate two major processes that are changing land cover: melting glaciers and ice sheets, and deforestation.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
Elaboration: They analyse these processes, explain their impacts on land cover and discuss responses to these land cover changes in two different locations in the world – one location for each process.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
Elaboration: Students evaluate two different global responses to the impacts of land cover change, one global response for each process.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse processes that result in changes to land cover and evaluate the impacts and responses resulting from these changes.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Land cover change
ContentDescription:
To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area 
of Study 1 and the relevant Characteristics of the study detailed on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Land use change
ContentDescription: In this area of study students select a local area and use appropriate fieldwork techniques and secondary sources to investigate the nature, processes and impacts of land use change.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Land use change
Elaboration: This change may have recently occurred, be underway or be planned for the near future.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Land use change
ContentDescription:
On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse land use change and evaluate 
its impacts.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: Students investigate the geography of human populations. They explore the patterns of population change, movement and distribution, and how governments, organisations and individuals have responded to those changes in different parts of the world.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: Students study population dynamics before undertaking an investigation into two significant population trends arising in different parts of the world. They examine the dynamics of populations and their environmental, economic, social, and cultural impacts on people and places.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: The growth of the world's population from 2.5 billion in 1950 to over 7 billion since 2010 has been on a scale without parallel in human history. Much of the current growth is occurring within developing countries while the populations in many developed countries are either growing slowly or are declining.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: Populations change through growth and decline in fertility and mortality, and by people moving to different places. The Demographic Transition Model and population structure diagrams provide frameworks for investigating the key dynamics of population.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: Population movements such as voluntary and forced movements over long or short terms add further complexity to population structures and to environmental, economic, social, and cultural conditions. Many factors influence population change, including the impact of government policies, economic conditions, wars and revolution, political boundary changes and hazard events.

Subject: Geography
ContentHeader: Unit 4: Human population: trends and issues
ContentDescription: Students investigate the interconnections between the reasons for population change. They evaluate strategies developed in response to population issues and challenges, in both a growing population trend of one country and an ageing population trend of another country, in different parts of the world.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
ContentDescription: In this area of study students undertake an overview of global population distribution and growth before investigating the dynamics of population change over time and space.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
Elaboration: Through the study of population dynamics, students investigate growth and decline in fertility and mortality, together with population movements.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
Elaboration: Students study forced and voluntary, and internal and external population movements and how they can be long term or short term.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
Elaboration: To illustrate the dynamics of population, students examine examples from within and between countries with different economic and political conditions and social structures.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
Elaboration: Students develop understanding of the Demographic Transition Model and its applications, and the Malthusian theory of population.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse and discuss population dynamics on a global scale.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Population dynamics
ContentDescription:
To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area 
of Study 1 and the relevant Characteristics of the study on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: Students undertake investigations into two countries with significant population trends in different parts of the world: a growing population of one country and an ageing population of another country.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: Students place these trends and resulting issues and challenges in their world regional context.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration: Issues resulting from these population trends include, among others, meeting the differing economic and social needs of the people for each country and the needs of the environment.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration: Students investigate issues arising from each population trend and the challenges that arise in coping with the issues.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration: Students study the interconnection between these issues and challenges with population dynamics.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: Students evaluate the effectiveness of strategies in response to these issues and challenges.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration: Strategies can be selected from government and/or non-government organisations.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration:
Comparison 
of strategies is undertaken within each selected country.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit the student should be able to analyse the nature of significant population issues and challenges in selected countries and evaluate strategies in response to these.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription:
To achieve this outcome the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area 
of Study 2 and the relevant Characteristics of the study detailed on pages 6–14.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration: All the key knowledge and key skills that underpin the outcomes in Units 3 and 4 are examinable.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: Duration: two hours.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: Date: end-of-year, on a date to be published annually by the VCAA.

Subject: Geography
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: VCAA examination rules will apply.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
Elaboration:
Details of these rules are published annually in the 
VCE Administrative Handbook.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Population issues and challenges
ContentDescription: The examination will be marked by assessors appointed by the VCAA.
